topic.title: HTML Comment Syntax
topic.description: HTML comments let developers annotate markup with notes that browsers ignore and users never see.

content.title: Comments Are Not Private
content.text: HTML comments are invisible in the browser viewport but fully visible in page source. Any user who presses Ctrl+U or opens DevTools can read every comment. Never put passwords, API keys, internal notes about security weaknesses, or sensitive business logic in HTML comments.

examples.title: HTML Comment Syntax, Placement, and Production Patterns
examples.description: This example covers every aspect of HTML comment usage: single-line and multi-line syntax, valid placement positions, the one syntax restriction to know, and the four comment patterns that appear most in production codebases: section labels, TODO notes, template placeholders, and conditional comments for legacy IE.

MULTI-LINE COMMENT (for longer notes): Everything between the delimiters is ignored, including line breaks and HTML tags.

This paragraph inside a comment does NOT render.

examples.output: Browser renders only the visible content: the nav, h1, two product cards with names and prices, and the copyright footer. Every comment is invisible in the viewport. The commented-out promo banner section does not render. Opening page source with Ctrl+U reveals all comments exactly as written. The section label banners, TODO notes, template placeholders, and disabled code block are all readable in source but produce no output.

examples.title: Comments in Development vs Production: Security and Performance
examples.description: This example shows the contrast between acceptable development comments and comments that should never reach production. It also demonstrates how build tools strip comments automatically and what kinds of information must never appear in client-side HTML regardless of environment.

examples.output: Browser renders only the nav, h1, and hero section paragraph. All comments are invisible in the viewport but fully readable in page source. The WRONG examples demonstrate what developers must never write in HTML. The build tool section explains that minifiers strip comments in production pipelines, but emphasises that security must never depend on comment removal.

when_to_use.point: When labeling major sections of a long template so teammates can navigate the file quickly
When temporarily disabling a block of markup during debugging without deleting it
When leaving TODO or FIXME notes in templates that need follow-up before launch

when_to_avoid.point: Avoid putting passwords, API keys, or any credentials inside HTML comments
Avoid leaving security weakness disclosures or internal business notes in comments
Avoid overusing comments for obvious markup, comment only what is genuinely unclear

what_it_solves.1: Without comments, long HTML templates have no internal landmarks and are slow to navigate.

what_it_solves.2: Comments allow markup to be temporarily disabled for testing without permanent deletion.

what_it_solves.3: TODO comments in templates keep pending work visible to the team without a separate task tracker.

conceptual_understanding.model: An HTML comment is like a sticky note placed on the outside of a sealed envelope. The postal system (the browser renderer) ignores the sticky note and delivers the letter as written. But anyone who handles the envelope on the way (anyone reading page source) can read every sticky note in full. The note is invisible to the letter's recipient but not secret.

Commenting out code in HTML is like covering a painting with a cloth in a gallery. The painting still exists in the room. Staff members who enter the storage area can see it. Only the public exhibition view hides it. Commented-out HTML still exists in the source file delivered to every visitor's browser, it is just not rendered on screen.

The double-hyphen restriction inside HTML comments exists because the original SGML parsing rules defined -- as the comment close signal. Two consecutive hyphens anywhere inside a comment body confuses parsers that follow the original rules. Modern HTML5 parsers are more lenient but the restriction remains in the specification to avoid cross-browser inconsistencies.

common_mistakes.mistake: Placing sensitive information in HTML comments: API keys, database credentials, internal endpoint paths, and security notes placed in comments are delivered to every visitor's browser in plain text. The comment being invisible in the rendered page provides no protection. Any person, bot, or search engine crawler that fetches the HTML can read every comment in the source.

Using double hyphens inside comment content: The HTML specification forbids two consecutive hyphens anywhere between the opening <!-- and closing --> other than as part of the closing delimiter itself. Writing <!-- a -- b --> is a parse error. Some browsers handle it gracefully, others treat the double hyphen as the end of the comment and render the following text as content.

Using comments for visual indentation or spacing instead of CSS: Some developers add blank comment lines between elements to create visual breathing room in the source. This has no effect on the rendered page. It increases file size, makes the source harder to scan, and does not replace the proper solution of CSS margin or padding for visual spacing between rendered elements.

bonus_tips.tip: In VS Code, press Ctrl+/ (Windows and Linux) or Cmd+/ (macOS) to toggle an HTML comment on any selected line or block. Select multiple lines and press the shortcut once to wrap them all in a single comment block, or to remove the comment delimiters if they are already there. This is the fastest way to comment out or uncomment sections during debugging.

Use a consistent comment convention across your team for section labels. A widely adopted pattern is opening with <!-- SECTION NAME --> and closing with <!-- /SECTION NAME -->, mirroring the way HTML tags open and close. This makes it immediately clear in long files where each major region ends, without needing to scroll back to find the opening comment.
